stage1.Abundance: Frequently fills joints in coal seams
stage1.Fact: Darkens with heating and may become magnetic

stage2.Habit: Rhombohedral with curved faces, columnar, granular, massive
stage2.Environment: Result of both hydrothermal, low-temperature metasomatism and banded iron formations
stage2.Name origin: Named after M. J. Anker, an Austrian mineralogist

stage4.Properties: Colour turns yellowish brown/brown when oxidation of iron has occured
stage4.Relevance: Large concentration of ankerite accompany galena-sphalerite-fluorite-baryte veins such as in the North Pennines orefield where limestone or quartz dolerite has been replaced
stage4.Optical: Increasing replacement of Mg by Fe2+ increases the refractive indices, birefringence and specific Gravity

Colours: White, colourless, grey, yellowish, reddish or green
stage1.Abundance: Extremely common on the seafloor as it forms in almost all mollusk shells, and as the calcareous endoskeleton of warm and cold water corals
stage1.Fact: Aragonite is considered essential for the replication of reef conditions in aquariums. It is the material that sea life is evolved to use and live around and also keeps the tank's pH close to its natural level

stage2.Countries: Facet-quality crystals come from the Czech Republic, superb cave growths from Mexico and flos-ferri from Austria and Greece
stage2.Habit: Prismatic, acicular, columnar or fibrous. Occasionally in branching stalactitic forms called “flos-ferri” meaning “flowers of iron” due to their association with ores at Carinthian iron mines
stage2.Environment: Sedimentary formations and evaporite deposits, hot spring deposits, hydrothermal Ore veins, igneous traprock environments, and metamorphic schists
stage2.Name origin: The type location for aragonite is Molina de Aragón (Guadalajara, Spain), 25 km from Aragon for which it was named in 1797

stage3.Further uses: Layered aragonite is sometimes polished and sold as 'onyx'

stage4.Relevance: Often found with iron ores and used in spar boxes
stage4.Impurities: Various Impurities lead to the vast selection of Colours described

stage1.Colours: White, yellow, brown, blue, green or red
stage1.Fact: It will glow green, blue or yellow under ultraviolet light

stage2.Uses: A component of heavy cement, it is crushed and screened to a uniform size
stage2.Countries: China, India, USA, Morocco, Turkey and Kazakhstan
stage2.Habit: Tabular, with a prismatic Habit giving the diamond-shaped outline with fibrous, coxcomb, granular and stalagmitic habits also being associated with this mineral
stage2.Environment: It is deposited during evaporation and biogenic processes and as a vein filling gangue mineral, as well as being identified in meteorites
stage2.Name origin: Derived from the Greek word βαρύς meaning heavy

stage3.Further uses: Varies the weight of well drilling mud in the production of petroleum which helps eliminate large differences in pressure between it, and the hydrocarbons, preventing kicks and subsequent catastrophic blow outs such as the incident in the Gulf of Mexico
stage3.Cleavage: Well observed, displaying perfect basal, and very good prismatic Cleavage

stage4.Properties: In the deep oceans, baryte crystallises out and forms a significant amount of sediments. With oxygen forming part of the crystal Structure, we can use it to gather paleotemperatures to a maximum of 25 Ma in conjunction with the  δ18O values. Similar variations of sulphur are also being exploited
stage4.Impurities: Yellow, red and brown caused by iron oxides, hydroxides, sulphides and organic matter whilst blue Colours indicate exposure of radiation

stage1.Abundance: Forms orientated druzy growths on baryte and calcite
stage1.Fact: Type locality is the Blagill Mine in the North Pennines. In the past lustrous, transparent, prismatic crystals of Barytocalcite have been found there

stage2.Environment: Forms in hydrothermal veins, especially where hydrothermal solutions have invaded limestone
stage2.Name origin: Derives its name from its components: barium and calcite

stage4.Relevance: It was first described in 1824 for an occurrence in the Blagill Mine in North Pennines

stage1.Colours: Usually colourless or white but shades of grey, yellow, green, red, purple, blue and even brown or black
stage1.Abundance: It is found in virtually every country as a major constituent in calcareous sedimentary rocks such as limestone and its metamorphic equivalent (marble)
stage1.Fact: Calcite refracts light, making you see two images instead of one

stage2.Uses: Fabricating Optical sights on weapons for World War II. Construction material, abrasive, agricultural soil treatment, construction aggregate, pigment, pharmaceuticals and more. It has more Uses than almost any other mineral
stage2.Countries: Stalagmites and stalactites are defining characteristics of limestone caverns which are found worldwide, particularly within tropical regions with the more well known ones recognised in Borneo, Iceland and Mexico. Salt rich bodies of water which dry up known as playa lakes or salt flats such as the World’s largest in Bolivia, are large sources of calcite
stage2.Habit: Varies more than any other mineral, most common being tabular and prismatic with fibrous, granular, stalactic or massive habits also observed
stage2.Environment: Hydrothermal veins and vugs, such as here in Weardale as well as caverns and marine organisms
stage2.Name origin: Derived from the greek word ‘Chalix’ meaning lime

stage3.Fracture: Conchoidal Fracture but rarely seen due to the perfect Cleavage

stage4.Properties: The phenomenon of double refraction causes a single dot on a piece of paper display 2 dots. If rotated, the true dot is stationary with the other rotating to the rhomb. It’s variable Habit indicates the depositional temperature conditions
stage4.Relevance: Gangue mineral, and used in spar boxes
stage4.Optical: Uniaxial, very common Twinning, with lamellar Twinning occurring due to exposure of high pressures
stage4.Impurities: Red due to iron while purple and blue indicate levels of niobium and brown or black include manganese

stage1.Colours: Usually white or grey but sometimes gray, blue, or green
stage1.Abundance: Namibia is perhaps the most classic locality for this mineral. Finer examples found in Morocco with excellent specimens from Australia, Italy, Weardale and Cornwall
stage1.Fact: Breaks down to a basic carbonate at about 300°, which, in turn, decomposes to lead oxide at about 500°

stage2.Uses: In ancient times lead was widely used for everything from water pipes to cooking pots, however due to our knowledge of its toxic and carcinogenic Properties, its applications have been limited. Lead still has many Uses in the modern world, from car batteries to the lining of roofs
stage2.Countries: Along with the localities listed previously, it also occurs in North and South America and Australia where it has been mined
stage2.Habit: Massive granular, reticulate, tabular to equant crystals
stage2.Environment: Occurs as a secondary mineral in oxidised lead veins
stage2.Name origin: From the latin name ‘cerussa’ meaning white lead

stage3.Further uses: Cerussite was once used as a white pigment

stage4.Relevance: An Ore of lead and silver
stage4.Optical: Biaxial with common contact or penetration twins
stage4.Impurities: Blue and green Colours typically indicate traces of copper

stage1.Colours: Purple varieties, blue, green, yellow, colourless
stage1.Abundance: Widely distributed occurring in veins either alone or as a gangue mineral with metallic ores
stage1.Fact: Many samples exhibit fluorescence under ultraviolet light - a property that takes its name from fluorite

stage2.Uses: Lowers the melting point in steel production. Used in the production of opalescent glass, enamels and cooking utensils. High grade fluorite used to make hydrogen fluoride and hydrofluoric acid.
stage2.Countries: China, Mexico, Mongolia, Russia, South Africa, Spain, Namibia
stage2.Environment: Vein deposits, often forms a part of the gangue
stage2.Name origin: Derived from the Latin fluo, in allusion to its readily fusible nature and its commercial use as a flux in smelting
stage2.Killhope colour: Brown, purple, violet, blue, green, colourless, grey, amber, white

stage3.Further uses: Ornamental and lapidary Uses. Commonly used as a window material for infrared and ultraviolet wavelengths in laboratories.

stage4.Properties: Calcium ions are arranged on a cubic fluorine lattice, a calcium ion is located at the centre of each cube face and each corner. Soluble in H2SO4
stage4.Relevance: In the North Pennine fluorite zone, purple and green fluorite occurs towards the centre while yellow is found towards the outer portions. Deposition temperatures of 90-220°C in the North Pennines calculated from studies on primary fluid inclusions in hydrothermal fluorite
stage4.Optical: Much discussion in cause of range of Colours in fluorite. Theories include element Impurities (allochromatic), physical disturbances in the crystal Structure, radioactive inclusions, traces of rare earth elements, presence of inclusions of carbonaceous material and emissions from nearby radioactive sources. In reality, the wide variety of Colours illustrated by fluorite can probably be affiliated to all of these factors

stage1.Abundance: Galena is found worldwide in a variety of different geologic environments due to its formation in low, intermediate and high temperature environments
stage1.Lustre: Metallic, however specimens tarnish when exposed to air becoming dull
stage1.Fact: The smelting of Galena can be achieved by nothing more complex than heating galena in the embers of a campfire and retrieving the metal from beneath when it cools

stage2.Uses: In ancient times lead was widely used for everything from water pipes to cooking pots, however due to our knowledge of its toxic and carcinogenic Properties, its applications have been limited. Lead still has many Uses in the modern world, from car batteries to the lining of roofs
stage2.Countries: Galena is a fairly common mineral and occurs in numerous locations worldwide. Galena is mined in Germany, Kosovo, Romania , and the U.S. tri-state mining district of Kansas, Missouri and Oklahoma
stage2.Habit: Fully grown crystals can be either coarse or fine grained and more rarely fibrous, crystals exceeding 2.5cm are common
stage2.Structure: Cubic and octahedral crystal systems, although the latter is rarely present alone. These crystals often grow on top of one another
stage2.Environment: In sedimentary limestone deposits, hydrothermal veins, hydrothermal replacement deposits, and in placer deposits. Rarely associated with basalts and diabase
stage2.Name origin: Named by Pliny the Elder in 77-79 from the Greek 'galene' meaning lead Ore

stage3.Further uses: One of its oldest known Uses was in Ancient Egypt where Egyptians would smear galena around their eyes to reflect sunlight and repel disease carrying insects. In many cases, galena contains Impurities such as Copper, Zinc, Bismuth and Silver. Often Galena can be made up of 1-2% silver, and this can be of greater value than the lead content making it also an important source of silver
stage3.Cleavage: Often exhibits a perfect cubic Cleavage with abundant triangular pits. This results in it deforming along it’s cube planes

stage4.Properties: Further Structural Information: Galena belongs to the octahedral sulfide group of minerals with metal ions in octahedral positions - 6 points, creating 8 faces. Alteration Properties: Within the weathering or oxidation zone galena alters to anglesite (lead sulfate), cerussite (lead carbonate), pyromorphite and pseudomorphs, which include chalcocite and covellite and can create overgrowths on one another. Isotopic information: The ratios of lead isotopes (206Pb, 207Pb and 208Pb) in Galena specimens allows the ages of the rock it is found in to be calculated. Associated Minerals: Galena often forms along side other minerals, in particular baryte, fluorite, quartz and calcite.
stage4.Relevance: Excellent Galena occurs in several places in England; the best include Alston Moor and Weardale, where it forms together with Fluorite
stage4.Optical: Optically isotropic, it reflects 42% of all light exposed to its surface
stage4.Impurities: Can include many different Impurities including silver, arsenic, antimony, and copper

stage1.Fact: Although originally defined as a single mineral, no longer scientifically considered a true mineral as it lacks a definitive chemical formula and crystal Structure.  Formula found to be a mixture of different minerals. Limonite is now considered a field term to describe hydrated oxides of iron with poorly crystalline character whose identity has not yet been determined

stage2.Uses: One of two primary iron ores (along side Hematite)
stage2.Environment: Common as a biogenic precipitate in swamps or as microscopic particles staining other minerals in weathered outcrops of metalliferous veins
stage2.Name origin: Named from the Greek word λειμών, meaning meadow, in allusion to its occurrence as a bog iron Ore

stage4.Properties: Commonly a product of iron-bearing minerals but can be found in all rocks. Mixture of related hydrated iron oxide minerals, chief mineralogical component is goethite. Individual minerals in limonite may form crystals but limonite does not, although it may show a fibrous or microcrystalline Structure. Limonite pseudomorphs can form through chemical weathering, transforming crystals of iron oxides, in particular pyrite, into limonite by hydrating the molecules, although the external shape remains that of the original mineral.
stage4.Relevance: Occurs as pseudomorphs of iron oxides in the North Pennine orefield
stage4.Optical: Normally isotropic but may allow anomalous birefringence

stage1.Colours: Most often seen in its colourless or milky white form, although it can also occur in many different coloured varieties
stage1.Abundance: After Silica, Quartz is the most abundant mineral in the Earth’s Crust. Quartz occurs in nearly all silica-rich metamorphic, sedimentary, and igneous rocks
stage1.Hardness: 7.0 (very hard, can only be scratched with metals such as tungsten)
stage1.Fact: Quartz was the mineral upon which the Stone Ages were based. With few exceptions, most early stone tools were fashioned of quartz

stage2.Uses: Quartz sand is often used in glass making. Quartz is also used as a gemstone as it is hard, durable, easy to shape and usually accepts a brilliant polish
stage2.Countries: United States (Arkansas), India, Brazil and Madagascar
stage2.Habit: Prismatic. Two forms - crystalline and cryptocrystalline (formed of microscopic crystalline particles)
stage2.Environment: Occurs in virtually every mineral Environment, often precipitating out of hydrothermal fluid
stage2.Name origin: The word Quartz comes from the German Quarz which is of Slavic origin (Czech miners called it křemen). Other sources attribute the word’s origin to the Saxon word Querkluftertz meaning cross-vein Ore

stage3.Further uses: All forms of quartz are used as gemstones, and they are all affordable. They are cut into various gemstone cuts and cabochons, and used in all forms of jewellry. Lesser quality stones are often tumbled for use in bracelets, necklaces, and as costume jewellry. Large spheres and carvings are also cut from all the quartz forms

stage4.Relevance: Gangue mineral and used in spar boxes
stage4.Optical: Uniaxial whilst showing a substantial variation of extinctions including the most reputable undulose extinction. Simple and lamellae Twinning can occur
stage4.Impurities: Smoky quartz - light brown, Milky quartz - white to greyish white, Rose quartz - translucent or transparent pink, Citrine - yellow to brownish quartz, Amethyst - vitreous quartz with purple, violet or red-purple colouration

stage1.Abundance: Widespread - found in sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic rocks
stage1.Ore: One of the iron carbonates (iron Ore)
stage1.Fact: It is a valuable iron mineral, since it is 48% iron and contains no sulfur or phosphorus

stage2.Uses: Siderites main use is for iron smelting, and it is a local but not a major source of iron
stage2.Countries: Iron is produced widely across the globe
stage2.Habit: Rhombohedral - Tabular crystals, often curved - botryoidal to massive
stage2.Environment: Well-formed crystals are usually found in hydrothermal veins. In sedimentary rocks it occurs at shallow burial depths as concretions and in thin beds with shale, clay, and coal seams. Well-formed crystals can also be found in some granitic and syenitic pegmatites
stage2.Name origin: It takes its name from the Greek word σίδηρος, sideros, meaning “iron”
stage2.Killhope colour: Brown to dark brown and green

stage3.Further uses: The smelting of iron from ores began in about 2000 BC in Persia. Iron proved a superior metal to bronze in almost every single way, and it’s use ultimately led to the Industrial Revolution. Siderite’s contribution as an Ore for iron has not yet been fully determined

stage4.Relevance: Economic value and used in spar boxes
stage4.Impurities: Color range from yellow to dark brown or black, the latter being due to the presence of manganese

stage1.Colours: White, blue, green, yellow, brown, pink, colourless
stage1.Abundance: Fairly common mineral found in the oxidation zone of most zinc deposits
stage1.Fact: First named ‘calamine’, it was renamed when it was discovered both smithsonite and hemimorphite had been grouped under the same name

stage2.Uses: Zinc is used for galvanizing steel, producing brass and bronze as well as zinc base alloys
stage2.Countries: Significant deposits in Italy, Greece, Namibia, Germany, Mexico, Zambia, US and Australia
stage2.Environment: Smithsonite occurs as a secondary mineral in the weathering or oxidation zone of zinc-bearing Ore deposits. It sometimes occurs as replacement bodies in carbonate rocks
stage2.Name origin: Named after James Smithson (1765-1829), English mineralogist who financed the founding of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, DC, USA

stage3.Further uses: Smithsonite is occasionally cut as ornaments and ‘en cabochon’ as gems

stage4.Relevance: Zinc Ore found in the area

stage1.Abundance: It is found in a multitude of Countries Worldwide
stage1.Lustre: Typically resinous while opaque specimens exhibit a shiny sub-metallic Lustre
stage1.Fact: Copper, silver and tin are often recorded in sphalerite

stage2.Uses: Crystals of suitable size and Transparency can be fashioned into gemstones
stage2.Countries: Sphalerite is produced worldwide, such as the Alston Moor, Germany, Switzerland, Canada and North and South America
stage2.Environment: Like Killhope, many deposits form where hydrothermal activity or contact metamorphism has brought hot, acidic, zinc-bearing fluids in contact with carbonate rocks
stage2.Transparency: Pure zinc sphalerites can be colourless and transparent, but iron will decrease translucency and the deepen the colour
stage2.Name origin: It takes its name from the Greek word spaleros meaning slippery/deceitful, as it was easily mistaken for galena

stage3.Further uses: The amount of iron that be accommodated in the sphalerite Structure increases with increasing temperature, therefore it can be used as a geological thermometer. Industrial Uses for zinc involve the production of brass and bronze alloys, an anti-corrosive in the galvanising of sheet steel and iron, galvanic elements, pigments such as zinc white, litopone, zinc yellow and in insecticides
stage3.Streak: Brown to light yellow or white Streak

stage4.Properties: Pure sphalerite transforms to the wurtzite polymorph at 1020°C if oxidation is prevented, but the inversion temperature is lowered by the presence of iron and manganese. Wurtzite can remain stable under 1020°C but any applied stress will convert it into sphalerite
stage4.Relevance: Major economic mineral associated with galena
stage4.Optical: Multiple contact twins, penetration twins  and lamellar intergrowths are common
stage4.Impurities: Green with cobalt and iron, red with tin, indium, silver and molybdenum and yellow often indicating a presence of carbon, copper, mercury, cadmium or germanium

stage1.Colours: White, colourless, yellow, brown or green
stage1.Fact: Can be lethal, the 18th-century naturalist Dr. Leigh recorded its lethal effects after the death of a farmer's wife and child after they came into contact with the mineral

stage2.Uses: Witherite has been used for hardening steel, and for making cement, glass, enamelware, soap, dye and explosives
stage2.Countries: Found in commercial quantities in England, France, Turkmenistan and Japan
stage2.Habit: Striated short prismatic crystals, also botryoidal to spherical
stage2.Environment: Found in low temperature hydrothermal vein deposits
stage2.Name origin: Named in 1790 after the mineralogist William Withering

stage3.Further uses: Up until the 18th century farmers at Anglezarke, Lancashire used the mineral as rat poison

stage4.Relevance: First recorded on Alston Moor, Northumberland. Found in the surrounding area in hydrothermal vein deposits
